A \(1000\) par value bond pays annual coupons of \(80\). The bond is redeemable at par in \(30\) years, but is callable any time from the end of the 10th year at \(1050\).
Based on her desired yield rate, an investor calculates the following potential purchase prices, \(P\) :

Assuming the bond is called at the end of the 10th year, P = 957
Assuming the bond is held until maturity, P = 897

The investor buys the bond at the highest price that guarantees she will receive at least her desired yield rate regardless of when the bond is called. The investor holds the bond for 20 years, after which time the bond is called.
Calculate the annual yield rate the investor earns.
Answer
We have

\(F = 1000\)
\(F \cdot r = 80\)
\(n = 30\) years, callable from \(t = 10\)
\(C = 1050\), given called at \(t=10\)

Let \(i\) be the annual yield rate of a
Solving for the yield rate given the bond is called at \(t=10\),
\[\begin{align*}
P &= F\cdot r \cdot a_{\enclose{actuarial}{n}i} + C \cdot v_i^n\\
957 &= 80 \cdot \left( \frac{1-(1+i)^{-10}}{i}   \right) + 1050 \cdot (1+i)^{-10}\\
i &= 0.0899911
\end{align*}\]
Solving for the yield rate given the bond is called at maturity,
\[\begin{align*}
P &= F\cdot r \cdot a_{\enclose{actuarial}{n}i} + C \cdot v_i^n\\
897 &= 80 \cdot \left( \frac{1-(1+i)^{-30}}{i}   \right) + 1000 \cdot (1+i)^{-30}\\
i &= 0.0900281
\end{align*}\]
Thus, the desired yield rate is \(0.0899911\%\)
We have \(r = 80/1000 = 8\% < i\), thus it is a discount case where the issuer would hold the bond as long as possible. Thus, the highest price that guarantees the desired yield rate will be received is \(897\)
However, since the bond was called at \(t=20\),
\[\begin{align*}
P &= F\cdot r \cdot a_{\enclose{actuarial}{n}i} + C \cdot v_i^n\\
897 &= 80 \cdot \left( \frac{1-(1+i)^{-20}}{i}   \right) + 1000 \cdot (1+i)^{-20}\\
i &= 0.0924304
\end{align*}\]
\(\therefore i \approx 9.24\%\)

A function \(f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}\) is said to be on \(\mathbb{R}\) if there exists \(p > 0\) such that \(f(x + p) = f(x)\) for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\). Prove that a continuous periodic function on \(\mathbb{R}\) is bounded and uniformly continuous on \(\mathbb{R}\)
Answer
Notice the following :
Let \(I := [0, p]\). Based on theorem, \(f\) must be bounded on \(I\) and uniformly continuous on \(\mathbb{R}\) or by definition \[\exists M > 0 \ni |f(x)| \leq M \; \forall x \in I\]
\[\forall \epsilon > 0 \; \exists \delta(\epsilon) > 0 \ni \forall x,c \in I, \; |x-c| < \delta(\epsilon) \implies |f(x) - f(c)| \leq \epsilon\]
Let \(x_k = x + kp\), and \(c_k = c + kp\) for all \(x,c \in I\) and \(n \in \mathbb{Z}\). Notice that \(x_n - c_n = x + kp - c - kp = x - c\), thus we have \[\exists M > 0 \ni |f(x)| = |f(x + kp)|  \leq M\]
\[\forall \epsilon > 0 \; \exists \delta(\epsilon) > 0 \ni \forall x,c \in I, \; |x_k - c_k| < \delta(\epsilon) \implies |f(x_n) - f(c_k)| \leq \epsilon\] Let \(I_k := [(k-1)p, p]\), thus \(x_k \in I_k \; \forall k \in \mathbb{Z}\) and from 2 condition above it assure that \(f\) must be bounded and uniformly continuous on \(I_k \; \forall k \in \mathbb{Z}\). It is trivial that \(\bigcup_{k \in \mathbb{Z}} \; I_k = \mathbb{R}\)
Therefore \(f\) is bounded and uniformly continuous on \(\mathbb{R}\)

\[F(x) = 1-\frac{\theta}{x}, \quad x>\theta\]
Loss observation: 9 below 10, 6 between 10 and 25, 5 in excess of 25
Find maximum likelihood estimator for \(\theta\)
Answer
\[\begin{align*}
L[\hat{\theta}] &= [F(10)]^9 \cdot [F(25)-F(10)]^6 + [S(25)]^5\\
&= \left[1-\frac{\theta}{10} \right]^9 \cdot \left[1-\frac{\theta}{25} - \left(1-\frac{\theta}{10} \right)\right]^6 \cdot \left[\frac{\theta}{25} \right]^5\\
&= \left[1- \frac{\theta}{10}\right]^9 \cdot \left[ \frac{3\theta}{50} \right]^6 \cdot \left[\frac{\theta}{25}\right]^5\\
\end{align*}\]
\[\begin{align*}
\ln{(L[\hat{\theta}])} = 9 \ln{1-\frac{\theta}{10}} + 6 \ln{\frac{3\theta}{05}} + 5\ln{\frac{\theta}{25}}\\
\frac{d}{d\theta}\ln{(L[\hat{\theta}])} &= \frac{-9}{10-\theta} + \frac{11}{\theta}\\
0&= \frac{110-20\theta}{(10-\theta)\theta}\\
\theta &= 5.5
\end{align*}\]
\(\therefore \hat{\theta} = 5.5\)

Explain why the sample mean may not be a consistent estimator of the population mean for a Pareto distribution.
Answer
By definition, an estimator is (weakly) consistent if it satisfies the following con dition:\
Let \(\hat{\theta_n}\) be an estimator of \(\theta\), if \(\forall \delta > 0\) and any \(\theta\), \(\lim_{n \to \infty} Pr(  \lvert \hat{\theta_n} - \theta \rvert > \delta) = 0\), then \(\hat{\theta_n}\) is a (weakly) consistent estimator of \(\theta\).\
Aside from definition, we can try to prove that the sample mean may not be a consistent estimator of the population mean for a Pareto distribution using the following theorem:\
If ${n } E[] = $ and ${n } Var[] = 0 $, then \(\hat{\theta_n}\) is (weakly) consistent.\
The expectation and variation of a Pareto distribution with parameter \((\alpha, \theta)\) are (with \(\alpha \geq 1 \cap 2)\):\
\[\begin{align}
    E[X] = \frac{\theta}{\alpha-1}\\
    Var[X] = \frac{\theta^2 \times \alpha}{ {(\alpha-1)}^2 \times (\alpha-2) }
\end{align}\]
We can immediately answer the question without using the above definition nor theorem (we may do so anyway later) and without involving the more complicated form of the expectation and variation of a Pareto distribution, observe that, if \(\alpha = 1\), the expectation would not exist, thus it is impossible for the sample mean, which will always exist to accurately estimate it.\
If we go to the page for Pareto distribution, we can also see that if \(\alpha <=1\), then the mean for the Pareto distribution would not exist, thus if we only use the sample mean, which does not account for the value of \(\alpha\) and will always exist, we cannot accurately estimate the mean for the Pareto distribution.\
Other Answer If we do not know the value of \(\alpha\), then if \(\alpha \leq 1\), we can see that: \[\begin{align*}
    \lim_{n \to \infty} E[\hat{\theta_n}] &= \lim_{n \to \infty} E[\theta]\\
    &= \infty
\end{align*}\] which is an inconclusive form and thus the limit does not exist and we cannot use the theorem to always prove that the mean sample is a (weakly) consistent estimator of a Pareto distribution mean.\

A function is called on an interval \(I\) if for any \(\epsilon > 0\) there exists \(\delta > 0\) such that for any pair-wise disjoint subintervals \([x_k, y_k]\), \(k = 1,2,...,n\), of \(I\) such that \(\sum|x_k - y_k| < \delta\) we have \(\sum|f(x_k) - f(y_k)| < \epsilon\). Show that if \(f\) satisfies a Lipschitz condition on \(I\), then \(f\) is absolutely continuous on \(I\)
Answer
\(f\) is a Lipschitz function on \(I\) and \([x_k, y_k] \subset I\) for all \(k\), thus by definition \[\exists M > 0 \ni |f(x_k) - f(y_k)| \leq M|x_k - y_k|\]
Thus we have \[\begin{align*}
    \sum |f(x_k) - f(y_k)| & = |f(x_1) - f(y_1)| + |f(x_2) - f(y_2)| + ... + |f(x_n) - f(y_n)| \\
    & \leq M(|x_1 - y_1| + |x_2 - y_2| + ... + |x_n - y_n|) \\
    & = M \sum|x_k - y_k| \leq M\delta
\end{align*}\]
Therefore if we choose \(\delta = \epsilon\) it follows that for any \(\epsilon > 0\) there exists \(\delta > 0\) where \(\delta = \epsilon\) such that for any pair-wise disjoint subintervals \([x_k, y_k]\), \(k = 1,2,...,n\), of \(I\) such that \(\sum|x_k - y_k| < \delta\) we have \(\sum|f(x_k) - f(y_k)| < \epsilon\)

Let \(f\) and \(g\) be Lipschitz functions on \(A\) (a). Show that the sum \(f + g\) is also a Lipschitz function on \(A\)
(b). Show that if \(f\) and \(g\) are bounded on \(A\), then the product is a Lipshictz function on \(A\)
(c). Give an example of a Lipschitz function \(f\) on \([0, \infty)\) such that itâ€™s square \(f^2\) is a Lipschitz function
Answer
(a). It will be shown that \(f + g\) is also a Lipschitz function on \(A\)
Because $f$ and $g$ is a Lipschitz function on $A$, then by definition
$$\exists K > 0 \ni |f(x) - f(c)| \leq K|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$$
\begin{center}
    and
\end{center}
$$\exists L > 0 \ni |g(x) - g(c)| \leq L|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$$

From the inequalty, we will have $$|(f(x) + g(x)) - (f(c) + g(c))| \leq |f(x) - f(c)| + |g(x) - g(c)| \leq (K + L)|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$$

Therefore $f + g$ is also a Lipschitz function on $A$ by definition because $\exists M > 0$ where $M = K + L$ such that $|(f(x) + g(x)) - (f(c) + g(c))| \leq M|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$ \\
(b). It will be shown that if \(f\) and \(g\) are bounded on \(A\), then the product is a Lipshictz function on \(A\)
Because $f$ and $g$ is a Lipschitz function on $A$, then by definition
$$\exists K > 0 \ni |f(x) - f(c)| \leq K|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$$
\begin{center}
    and
\end{center}
$$\exists L > 0 \ni |g(x) - g(c)| \leq L|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$$

We also know that $f$ and $g$ is bounded on $A$, thus
$$\exists K_1 > 0 \ni |f(x)| \leq K_1 \; \forall x \in A$$
\begin{center}
    and
\end{center}
$$\exists L_1 > 0 \ni |g(x)| \leq L_1 \; \forall x \in A$$

Notice that
\begin{align*}
    |f(x)g(x) - f(c)g(c)| & = |f(x)g(x) - g(x)f(c) + g(x)f(c) - f(c)g(c)| \\
    & = |g(x)(f(x) - f(c)) - f(c)(g(x) - g(c))| \\
    & \leq |g(x)||f(x) - f(c)| + |f(c)||g(x) - g(c)| \\
    & \leq L_1K|x-c| + K_1L|x-c| \\
    & = (L_1K + K_1L)|x-c|
\end{align*}

Therefore $fg$ is also a Lipschitz function on $A$ by definition because $\exists M > 0$ where $M =(L_1K + K_1L)$ such that $|(f(x)g(x)) - (f(c)g(c))| \leq M|x - c| \; \forall x,c \in A$ \\
(c). Let \(f(x) = x\). It is trivially follow that \(f\) is Lipschitz function on \([0, \infty)\). It will be shown that \(f^2(x) = x^2\) is not a Lipschitz function on \([0, \infty)\) by contradiction
Let $A := [0, \infty)$ and assume that $f^2$ is a Lipschitz function on $A$. Then it must follow that $\exists K > 0 \ni |x^2 - c^2| \leq K|x-c| \; \forall x,c \in A$

Notice that $|x^2 - c^2| = |x-c||x+c|$, and because $x,c \in A$ it follows that $x + c = |x+c|$ thus $|x^2 - c^2| = |x-c|(x+c)$. Because $A$ does not have an upper bound, then $x + c$ also does not have an upper bound, thus we can't choose $K > 0$ such that $x + c \leq K$ which contradicts our assumption that $|x^2 - c^2| \leq K|x-c|$

Therefore our assumption must be false, which means $f^2$ is not a Lipschitz function on $A$
